newsitem.title: USA: Moody's, S&P preparing reports on Calif initiative.
newsitem.headline: Moody's, S&P preparing reports on Calif initiative.

text.p: Moody's Investors Service Inc and Standard & Poor's Corp said Monday they were preparing reports on a California proposition that would limit the ability of local governments to raise taxes and fees.
Moody's Vice President David Brodsly said the rating agency was expected to issue its report on proposition 218 within the next two weeks.
"It's probably not a good thing for credit," said Brodsly of the proposition. "But we haven't completed our analysis to really speak to the broader implications."
S&P Director David Hitchcock said S&P was also preparing to issue a report on the proposition.
"We're going through our list of ratings right now to see if there are any ratings that would be affected," he said.

Proposition 218 would limit the authority of local governments to impose taxes and property-related assessments, fees and charges. It would require a majority of voters to approve increases in general taxes and reiterate that two-thirds of voters must approve special taxes.
Under the proposition, assessments, fees and charges would have to be submitted to property owners for approval.
As previously reported, Stone & Youngberg LLC and other municipal finance firms have warned of the implications of the initiative, which will appear on the November 5 ballot.
Stone & Youngberg recommended that its clients vote against the measure because of the "devastating effect the initiative will immediately have on local government finance."
